segments.en: Linked Discourses 4
1. Life Span
1. Mortification
So I have heard.

segments.pli: ekaṃ samayaṃ bhagavā uruvelāyaṃ viharati najjā nerañjarāya tīre ajapālanigrodhamūle paṭhamābhisambuddho.
segments.en: At one time, when he was first awakened, the Buddha was staying near Uruvelā at the root of the goatherd’s banyan tree on the bank of the Nerañjarā River.

segments.pli: Atha kho bhagavato rahogatassa paṭisallīnassa evaṃ cetaso parivitakko udapādi:
segments.en: Then as he was in private retreat this thought came to his mind,
“I am truly freed from that grueling work!

segments.pli: Sādhu mutto vatamhi tāya anatthasaṃhitāya dukkarakārikāya.
segments.en: Thank goodness I’m freed from that pointless grueling work.
Thank goodness that, steadfast and mindful, I have attained awakening.”

segments.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā bhagavato cetasā cetoparivitakkamaññāya yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṃ gāthāya ajjhabhāsi:
segments.en: And then Māra the Wicked, knowing what the Buddha was thinking, went up to him and addressed him in verse:
“You’ve departed from the practice of mortification
by which humans purify themselves.
You’re impure, but think yourself pure;
you’ve strayed from the path of purity.”

segments.pli: Atha kho bhagavā “māro ayaṃ pāpimā” iti viditvā māraṃ pāpimantaṃ gāthāhi ajjhabhāsi:
segments.en: Then the Buddha, knowing that this was Māra the Wicked, replied to him in verse:
“I realized that it’s pointless;
all that mortification in search of immortality
is as futile
as oars and rudder on dry land.
Ethics, immersion, and wisdom:
by developing this path to awakening
I attained ultimate purity.
You’re beaten, terminator!”

segments.pli: Atha kho māro pāpimā “jānāti maṃ bhagavā, jānāti maṃ sugato”ti, dukkhī dummano tatthevantaradhāyīti.
segments.en: Then Māra the Wicked, thinking, “The Buddha knows me! The Holy One knows me!” miserable and sad, vanished right there.

suttaplex.blurb: Māra accuses the Buddha of having abandoned the path of true austerity.
